title: Wall Street's capital recycling machine still humming
text:
The US market is the best source of momentum, and the British market the best source of value, according to Citi’s head of equity strategy, who says shareholders in both markets do a great job at keeping listed companies honest.

US stocks have been the "leading trade of this cycle", Robert Buckland said. “We are still long because we think that the economic story is a bit better in the US, and we think that the companies are a bit better in the US."

This is because shareholders expect a great deal. If companies are not thriving on Wall Street, the market replaces them with better companies that are performing.

“What the US does is create new companies and that’s a profound difference compared to other developed markets,” the strategist said. “I like that element. It shows that it’s good at recycling capital."

Investors "are more demanding”, Mr Buckland said. “The US is my momentum trade."

Britain, on the other hand, is his value trade. “I think that the Brexit risk premium offers opportunities. In the UK, if a company trades on a low multiple for a period of time, something will happen,” he said. “But in other cheap markets, such as Japan, nothing will happen.”
description: Citi’s global head of equity strategy says that demanding shareholders ensure cheap US and UK stocks don't stay cheap.
